questions.question_text: A cybersecurity analyst is reviewing the current BYOD security posture. The users must be able to synchronize their calendars, email, and contacts to a smartphone or other personal device. The recommendation must provide the most flexibility to users. Which of the following recommendations would meet both the mobile data protection efforts and the business requirements described in this scenario?

choices.B: Implement a single computer configured with USB access and monitored by sensors.
choices.D: Implement a wireless network configured for mobile device access and monitored by sensors.
choices.C: Deploy a kiosk for synchronizing while using an access list of approved users.
choices.A: Develop a minimum security baseline while restricting the type of data that can be accessed.

discussion.content: I think this is D. Implementing a wireless network configured only for mobile devices will provide flexibility to users as they can connect any kind of device to the wireless network. Admins also can increase security by limiting/preventing specific traffic going to internal network from the wireless network.

A - Protected? ("Minimum baseline"), Not Flexible? ("Restricting)
B - Sorta Protected? ("USB access", "Monitored by sensors"), Not Flexible ("Single Computer")
C - Protected ("List of approved users"), Not Flexible? ("kiosk for synchronization")
D - Protected ("Monitored by sensors"), Flexible ("Wireless")

Are these the reasons for D? (I picked C originally)
I think the answer might be A, D doesn't provide flexibility to users.

I think since the network will be monitored by sensors, there will be a list of approved device from each employee allowed by the sensor, any other device will then be denied access. this also makes choice C a valid one.
Why D? What happens to company data when user is not on the wireless network?
A WAF or web application firewall helps protect web applications by filtering and monitoring HTTP traffic between a web application and the Internet.

choices.A: The security analyst should recommend this device be placed behind a WAF.
choices.B: The security analyst should recommend an IDS be placed on the network segment.
choices.D: The security analyst should recommend this device be included in regular vulnerability scans.
choices.C: The security analyst should recommend this device regularly export the web logs to a SIEM system.

questions.question_text: A security analyst has determined that the user interface on an embedded device is vulnerable to common SQL injections. The device is unable to be replaced, and the software cannot be upgraded. Which of the following should the security analyst recommend to add additional security to this device?

Several users have reported that when attempting to save documents in team folders, the following message is received:
The File Cannot Be Copied or Moved "" Service Unavailable.
Upon further investigation, it is found that the syslog server is not obtaining log events from the file server to which the users are attempting to copy files. Which of the following is the MOST likely scenario causing these issues?

choices.C: Malicious processes are running on the file server
choices.D: All the available space on the file server is consumed
choices.A: The network is saturated, causing network congestion
choices.B: The file server is experiencing high CPU and memory utilization

discussion.content:
This is D.

When copying files to the server it returns an error and logs is not being transfer from the server since the whole disk space is consumed. Network saturation only slows the transfer/network.

comments.content:
I think this is D, network saturation is a temporary condition not permanent.
Full disk usage is permanent.

discussion.content:
Answer is A - 
The clue to this is
" Upon further investigation, it is found that the syslog server is not obtaining log events from the file server to which the users are attempting to copy files."
So data from server to SIEM is not happening. hence Network saturation. 

Although I certainly get why you would choose the other answers.
B is a much better option here.
correlation analysis by log for threat management Is SIEM

questions.question_text: Which of the following is MOST effective for correlation analysis by log for threat management?

A cybersecurity analyst has been asked to follow a corporate process that will be used to manage vulnerabilities for an organization. The analyst notices the policy has not been updated in three years. Which of the following should the analyst check to ensure the policy is still accurate?

discussion.content: Isn't this D - governing regulations. By checking the regulations that affects/governs the org, they can know if there is already a change on how they should handle vulnerabilities - whether how frequent scans should be conducted, etc. Threat intelligence reports won't affect how an org conducts its entire vulnerability management process - it will only affect which vulnerabilities to prioritize/focus on.
I agree with s3curity1. It makes sense to check the regulations etc.
The answer should be D to verify an updates to regulations and governance. Option A makes no sense
